page.title: 10TEIGNMOUTH'S DOCKS
page.content: The Docks started in the 13th century with salt production and grew in the 16th century with Newfoundland fish. Around 1740 ball clay from Bovey Tracey was exported and in the 19th century Dartmoor granite was shipped to London (for the Bridge). Today the Quay Co. employs about 60 men and the docks handle about 550 ships each year. Winter is the busiest time and so is the start of each week.210,000 out of 246,000 tonnes of exports are clay which goes to Rotterdam for distribution. Imports total is 472,000 tonnes, of which 197,000 is animal feed and 112,000 was coal in 1984 because of the strike. The Docks are probably the biggest source of employment in the town being used by lorries from 50 local firms. Some locals object to dust and noise.
